description: I really liked this.

Very nice GNOME Dictionary application, has good definitions, but:
1. Needs a child mode, as has unwanted words that i would not want to show to my kids.
2. Needs integration for giving meaning from a search in the Activities Overview in GNOME Shell. This particular feature would bring GNOME Shell on-par with MacOS. Very good app, though.
summary: Very good, needs integration with GNOME Shell's Overview

description: It is good for for what it is but doesn't satisfy my needs, I wish if it sports an offline mode, does word suggestions/corrections, sports a better and more clean GUI for picking dictionaries and over all GNOME integration such as highlighting a word in Epiphany, gedit, etc and launching GNOME Dictionary with the word already pasted and defined like in WordWeb as well as integration with Orca or other technology or app to pronounce words when needed.

GNOME Dictionary really falls short of being useful. Its total reliance on Internet connectivity, with no local dictionary databases, and its bug-ridden and unstable window UI make for a pretty poor leading dictionary for the GNOME desktop environment. 

Verdict: this feels like a beta app. Needs work, and a lot of it. Please improve its practical use range and working design (backend). Use local dictionaries and expand the search with online content when available. Add a GNOME Shell service. Get rid of UI bugs.
I like GNOME apps.
Why not make it available offline? The only good one I found after searching through loads of options was Artha.
I do not know why its can not work even I search a very simple word like cat.
summary: It cannot search such a simple word

description:
What I like about this is that (1) it searches through a vast number of references. (2) It's the only Internet dependent dictionary I have ever seen that automatically provides word roots, and pronunciation, AND parts of speech. (Yayyy!)
I find myself turning to it a lot.
Drawbacks? I would like to see a sidebar with a list of possibilities when I misspell a word, instead of "error" and a blank stare, or a look ahead dropdown list (?) That does not keep me from using it.
Other than that - it's an EXCELLENT language tool.
Try it!
Requiring internet connectivity all the time is not good. The application should really have an offline dictionary.
summary: Requiring internet connectivity all the time is not good

There's very little to like about this application. Looking up words seems to fail frequently, I searched on many common terms which failed and then double checked while writing this review and it then found them. The UI is not user friendly. As others have pointed out, it cannot be used offline which is exactly when a classic desktop app would be most useful.

description:
The word definitions are harder to navigate, the results are just too confusing ( I searched for "what" ).

On top of it, the lookup requires internet.

QuickWord, another dictionary app, can perform highlight to lookup and has local database where definitions are much easier to navigate.

GNOME Dictionary being an official app, it just doesn't live up to GNOME's reputation.
summary: GNOME Dictionary is pretty but that's everything good about it

description: It has many dictionaries added by default, but the text showed is just text plane and it looks like a mess.

- Quick to load which is what you want
- Simple UI as per gnome

I don't want to load a browser, then a tab, then wait for dictionary.com to load all of it's cruft just to check a word
summary: Does the job when you want a quick word lookup

description: I was very happy when I found this app. Maybe I had to high of expectations, IDK. It has a terrable interface, there is no built in dictionary. I could understand building this app if it was 1992 and dictionaries exisisted in plain-text format only. This just takes data from another source and punches it in to a crappy UI, like why bother? Only dictionaries are a far better resource when you need to write somthing.

While it's nice to have a dictionary, I am tired enough of all the "cloud" services that try to monetize my personal life and do not want an app that has to fetch everything from the web. If my network is down, then it's useless and providing a list of words I search to whatever blaggard happens to run any of the servers involved is pernicious.

DICT protocol, which is used by this app, is unsupported by major up to date dictionaries. Predefined dictionary server seems to be the only available one and is not enough (but not bad either, just OK).
Also as other reviews point out plain text output is too primitive. While it can be used to quickly look up concise defenitions, some of suggested dictionaries produce cumbersome initial parts for the words defenitions which are inconvenient to read in plain text format.

works as intended, very light and fast. The only downside is that requires internet connection to work. It would be great to have an option to download some sources. It is also not easy to change dictionaries as the search funtion when changing dicts does not seem to work. It would be great to have a option to have a keybind to open the app and search for the definition of whatever is currently selected
Super slow to translate even just a word..
its pretty simple, but pretty good, it just does what it does, thats pretty much it, no special stuff, just gets straight to the point, only thing i would want in this app is dark mode.
Nice app! It would be useful to have an option to download dictionaries so that you could use it ofline as well.
